Zhizong, the Great Master of Tonghui at Tianshou Temple on the Left Street of the Song Dynasty
Compiled by the Purple-robed Monk Zanning and others by imperial order
Zhiyuan, a monk of Huayan Temple on Mount Wutai in the Tang Dynasty, whose secular surname was Song, was from Runan.
His father passed away early, and he served his widowed mother alone, without time for morning and evening due to the etiquette of serving her.
His mother always recited the Lotus Sutra, and was proficient in five scrolls.
Zhiyuan had clear understanding and outstanding talent, and was unique.

At the age of twenty-eight, he left his parents to follow a teacher, taking refuge in the teachings of Heshang. He understood the profound meaning and managed monastic affairs for six years in succession.
In all matters of provision, he never mixed them up.
Since then, he left his teacher and visited again, spending another eight years. Although he was well-versed in both traditions, his feelings were still attached.
He heard that the Tiantai school comprehensively includes the wondrous principles, with samÄdhi and prajÃ±Ä both merged, understanding and practice.
The ten modes of contemplation of the realm arise from this school.
The three virtues of cultivation and nature are fully expounded by Qingliang.

He then ordered his peers to follow him to the Five Peaks, to dwell in the forests and springs, to tread the previous steps, to understand the principles of the six realms of existence and four noble truths, to comprehend the gate of revealing, understanding, awakening, and entering, to encompass the nature and characteristics of the hundred realms and thousand suchnesses.
It is both obstruction and illumination, with destruction and establishment occurring simultaneously.
The perfect interfusion of the phenomenal and the noumenal, and the equality of the ordinary and the sacred, open the eyes of the mind, and the self and others are both absent.
In just over forty years, his exposition was unique.
Yuan's work was refined and his way was profound, his will was bitter and his spirit was harmonious, he did not unrobe while lying down, and he did not eat separately requested meals.
At that time, the years were poor, and the supply of firewood and rice was often disrupted. Every time he scooped up water to rinse his mouth, he hoped it would last for a long time.
His body had sores and scabies, but he did not apply ointment with his hands. He strictly observed the precepts and was cautious in mind and speech.
He always refined his body and mind with the four kinds of samÄdhi.
As for sealing letters and writing, he was quite skilled in elegant calligraphy and seal script.

Whenever there were people in the monastic and lay communities who were proud of their talent and learning, they were amazed by his eloquence. Some would search for obscure and hidden [teachings] to try to defeat him, watch for his faults, and seek his victory or defeat.

Although he would advance with arrogance and sit in the seat, he would retreat with a humble and submissive appearance. When they came, he would make their mountain of self-importance high, and when they left, he would let it collapse in four ways.

In the fourth year of the Huichang era, at the age of seventy-seven, and having been a monk for forty-eight years, he suddenly stopped eating for several days, yet he did not tire of teaching the Dharma.
On the seventeenth day of the second month, he warned his disciples, saying:
Since I was born, I have cultivated and progressed, not deceiving my mind and mouth. Now I have attained two kinds of karmic rewards.
Sleeping peacefully, waking peacefully, and being free from pain and distress.
He also said:

The commentaries on the Tiantai school are dedicated to spreading the teachings. The Fahua Shu in ten scrolls, the two gates of the original and traces, the three periods of prediction, revealing the near and showing the far.
The Xuanwen in ten scrolls, the five meanings of interpretation.

The Zhiguan in ten scrolls, the dual cultivation of contemplation and insight, the indefinite sudden and gradual, the coarse and wonderful of the eight teachings, the equality of obstruction and illumination, the perfect understanding of practice and insight, the mutual inclusion of one and many. The Wenju in one scroll, polishing jade and polishing gold, about to tread the holy steps, rarely reaching this.
The ritual repentance and the Vaipulya sutras must rely on sincerity. Keep this in mind forever, and live up to my intention.
At that time, the dragons and elephants gathered like clouds, filling the corners of the seats, all praising the rarity, and chanting the Buddha's name together.

When the compassionate teachings were about to end, the spirit suddenly passed away. The wind was sorrowful and the clouds were sad, the mountains were dark and the waters choked, the colors of the forests and hills changed, and the disciples were deeply saddened.
On the day of cremation, the disciples ran around, not knowing where to go.
Although there were many students, only Yuan Kan, who was from the Ma clan of Fufeng, understood his Dharma.

His bearing was profound, and his way of life was originally lofty. He was able to turn the bottle of liberation and pour it into the vessel of ghee. It can be said that after one lamp, another lamp is lit.

When Emperor Wuzong cleared away Buddhism, he followed his teacher's previous instructions, grieving and wailing for many nights, hiding his chapters, commentaries, and texts in the walls of his house.

When Emperor Xuanzong revived Buddhism, he rebuilt his old residence, took his teachings, placed them in the shadow hall, and practiced the six periods of walking meditation as if he were still alive.
The wonderful sutra of the Lotus was chanted for many years;
The MahÄyÄna samÄdhi was expounded for a long time.

Shi Xiyuan, whose surname was Zhang, was a person from Suzhou.
His clan was wealthy and powerful, but he alone left home to follow and receive the precepts. He then traveled to lecture halls.

He did not stay in one place, but diligently practiced the three learnings. As the years passed, he became even more widely knowledgeable, and was pushed by his contemporaries as outstanding. He was then ordered to lecture and instruct.
During the Guangqi period, Xu Yao's army caused chaos, and Sun Ru briefly controlled the land. The imperial garden was in turmoil.
Xiyuan left Tongxuan Temple and took a merchant ship to avoid going to the east of Yong.
The merchant who accompanied him was also a person from Yue. He deeply respected Xiyuan and invited him to reside at Baolin Temple on Mount Hui in Kuaiji.
Although his appearance was insignificant, his nature was strong and capable. He rarely associated with the times and often engaged in silent meditation.
When asked about this, he said:
I am at ease in the realm of formlessness, just like a lion playing.
In the Jingfu era, at the mountain temple, he expounded the sutras and treatises, with harmonious voices responding to each other, and those who sought the Dharma arrived.
He then wrote several fascicles of the Profound Commentary, all of which were wonderful in meaning and expression.
He always encouraged people to quickly cultivate the practice of rebirth in the Pure Land, saying:
It is not difficult to know, but difficult to practice.
You should strive for it.
He always performed the six periods of repentance and chanting without the slightest omission.
His small room was located on the peak of Langya Mountain. It is said that the mountain flew over from Langya Terrace. This place was originally a slaughterhouse, so it was all suppressed below it.
The well in the mountain house had eels, and the water would expand and contract in response to the tide of the great river, with many strange phenomena.
One says that this place was where Yu locked up the dragons and sea monsters of Zhejiang, called chi.
The maggots have two ears, and their color is bluish-yellow. If they cling to bamboo or wood, it means that wind and rain will come.
Now they sometimes emerge from stone crevices and enter the ditches and canals of the monks' dwellings. When they see people, they are not startled. If grasped, they jump and writhe as if angry.

They only enter the rooms of those with the surname Yuan. When held by someone with the surname Yuan, they roll and wriggle, and then they accept the three refuges and precepts, and are told not to create the demon of wind and hail.
After Yuan passed away, there were many violent storms and rain.
Yuan practiced and wished to see Maitreya.

One day during a lecture, he sat upright and passed away on the Dharma seat. At that time, the assembly smelled a strange fragrance, and heavenly music sounded, sometimes stopping and sometimes continuing, for seven days. After that, this is truly the proof of rebirth in the upper realms, isn't it?
This was in the second year of Qianning, in the fourth month.
On the day of returning to the mountain, the monks set up a memorial at the temple gate.
Suddenly, someone in a red robe with an elephant-seal appeared, bowed and knelt down, deeply moved.
In a daze, there was no trace to be found, and the crowd could not fathom it.

The Biography of Xuanjue of the Wooden Pagoda Cloister of Longxing Temple in Jiangzhou during the Tang Dynasty, Part 2.
Shi Xuanjue, whose surname was Zhang, was from Zhengping.

His aspirations were upright and pure, and he had the desire to leave the dust from a young age. Having fulfilled his long-cherished wish, he entered Longxing Monastery in the prefecture. He recited a thousand words a day, and did not need to receive them again.
After shaving his head, he fully observed the precepts. He examined his own mind and followed the precepts. He diligently upheld the precepts and prohibitions, never violating them.
From this point on, his reputation and integrity suddenly rose, and his peers looked up to him.
In a few years, he became proficient in the Vinaya and treatises. He sought knowledge everywhere and delved into the profound texts.

He stayed at Chongsheng Temple in Chang'an, and was selected for his precepts and virtue to preside over the ordination platform. He lectured on the Vinaya and the Abhidharma-koÅ›a more than 40 times. He was profound and still by nature, and his investigation was faultless.
He wrote the Jin Hua Commentary on the Abhidharma-koÅ›a in 20 volumes, which was valued by the time.
And when he ascended the lecture seat for the two lectures, there were more than 300 people, all of whom studied under him.
He had more than 100 disciples who transmitted and received his teachings. Even in his old age, students flocked to him between the Fen and Qin rivers.
He passed away in a small room in the original temple. His secular age was 76, and his age as a monk was 56.
His Dharma disciples, both monastic and lay, collected the relics from the cremation and burial, and obtained several hundred grains. They built a brick pagoda to the west of the county seat.

The Biography of Yan Hui of Mingfu Temple in Liangshu Prefecture, the Biography of Yan Hui of Mingfu Temple in Liangshu Prefecture, Shi Yan Hui, whose surname was Sun, was from Yangwu County in Dongjing.
In the year of Peiqi, he heard his father reading the Diamond Prajna Paramita Sutra, and listened with wide eyes, joyfully serene.
Moreover, when the family was holding a vegetarian feast for monks, with the sound of the bell and chanting, he joined his palms in delight under the curtains.
At the age of fifteen, he followed his teacher to study the Dharma, going to Taiyuan, Jingzhao, and Luoyang to listen and learn tirelessly.
When he was of age, he received full ordination at Shaoshi Temple on Mount Song, and studied the Vinaya, becoming quite proficient in the profound meaning.
Next, he studied the sutras and sastras, exploring the mysteries of all of them.
He said:
Doing good is not the same, but it all leads to governance.
Governance is about precepts, concentration, and wisdom.
Entering the mechanism of sainthood, these three are the ultimate in governing one's nature.
When he arrived in Luoyang, the pioneers all admired and submitted to him.
By the time the four groups all looked up to his gentleness and clarity, when facing a mirror he was slightly displeased but mostly delighted, and when holding a bottle he felt light and heavy.
Apart from the three robes, the hundred and one necessities are provided in moderation, with nothing extra.
The practiced compassion and patience are not matters of seeking.
Not keeping disciples, only exhausting one's own efforts, diligently transforming and guiding, silently progressing and cultivating.
Therefore, the people of Nanyue call him the Buddha's disciple.

First staying at Mingfu Temple, lecturing on the Hundred Dharmas Treatise, the talented people from the four seas flocked like waves, always overflowing with over a hundred, and many were outstanding, thoroughly researching the treatise seats and reverently studying the sutra's principles.
Among them, those with extensive learning and talent were divided into upper and lower ten evils.
The ten evils are like the titles of the eight dukes.

The upper ten evils thoroughly understand nature and characteristics, erect the Dharma banner high, and in the three of thesis, reason, and example, there is no obstruction in establishing or refuting.

Below, the ten evils are studied internally and externally, reciting wind and waves, discussing and debating the sutras, with clear voice and quick tongue, praising and chanting the Sanskrit verses, and proclaiming the teachings.
It is because the division of the titles is the culmination of talent. Saying evil is a word of inversion, which is utmost goodness.
This is how his disciples are.

Hui lectured on the two treatises of Hetuvidya and the Treatise on One Hundred Dharmas more than a hundred times each, produced over one hundred and fifty disciples, and wrote commentaries called Slit Platform, which became popular in the world.
On the third day of the eighth month in the autumn of the first year of Qianhua, he suddenly passed away with his strength exhausted.
He was seventy-two years old, and had been a monk for fifty-two years.

The people of Huai followed and missed his virtue, and the two groups of more than three hundred people carried his sacred coffin back to be buried beside Yangwu County, and built a small pagoda there.

Biography of Guishu of Xiangguo Temple in the Eastern Capital of the Liang Dynasty, Biography of Guishu of Xiangguo Temple in the Eastern Capital of the Liang Dynasty, Shi Guishu, whose surname was Mei, was a person from Shouchun.

His father Yuanxu knew that his son was intelligent and sharp, so he taught him the Book of Poetry and the Book of Documents. He memorized and recited them, and his understanding surpassed that of others.

While following the other children, he secretly wished to leave the dust. His parents agreed to his frequent requests, so he took Daozong, the Vinaya Master of Kaiyuan Temple in his native prefecture, as his teacher.
Before he was even ten years old, he memorized the two sutras Lotus Sutra and Humane Kings Sutra.

When he reached the age of twenty, he fully received the precepts. He was strict in observing the three kinds of actions and never neglected the four kinds of deportment. He studied the new chapters and soon became proficient in lecturing and teaching.
Later, he heard that the sutras and treatises were flourishing in the three capitals of Luoyang, so he formed a group and sought a teacher.

In just ten years, he thoroughly understood nature and characteristics, the Mahayana and Hinayana, the branch of names and numbers, the study of logic, the Abhidharma-koÅ›a, the VijÃ±aptimÄtratÄ, the VimalakÄ«rti-nirdeÅ›a-sÅ«tra, and the Sutra of the Buddha's Life Above, all as profound as empty space.
He then went to Nanyue to study under Master Hui, reviewing what he had learned, and further refined his understanding, still feeling that the doctrinal chapters were not yet perfect.
He then went to Xiangguo Temple in the Eastern Capital and finally compiled the New Notes, lecturing and instructing with utmost diligence, and his disciples understood.
At that time, the last ruler of the Zhu clan was a classmate of Yu's when they were young, and they were close friends with deep feelings, separated for many years.
Half a year after ascending the throne, he issued an edict to inquire about Yu.
Although Yu knew his old friend, he did not speak for a whole year.
The matter could not be avoided, and he responded to the summons and entered.
The emperor was both sad and happy upon seeing him, and bestowed abundant gifts.

At that time, it was the Jiaqing Festival, and an edict had been issued to stop the bestowal of honors on monks and Daoists throughout the country. That year, Xu alone was granted purple robes and the title of Great Master of Expounding the Dharma.
The ceremonial guards of the two streets welcomed and escorted him to the temple, and an imperial edict was issued to make the Dongta Imperial Portrait Hall a long-lasting lecture hall.

At that time, the military governor of Fujian presented a set of the Diamond Sutra and three hundred bolts of silk for the sacred festival, all of which were bestowed upon Xu, to the honor of the Dharma community.

However, seeing that the old commentaries had some points that were not satisfactory and did not fully grasp the principles, he then delved into the essential meaning for three years and completed twenty volumes, calling it the Grass Script Essentials of the Sutra, which he copied and presented.
The emperor read it with admiration and ordered it to be included in the canon, but Xu firmly declined.
In this way, for fifteen years, he tirelessly promoted the teaching, and his disciples Rong and Shang Gong successively carried it on.
On the tenth day of the tenth month in the third year of Qingtai in the Later Tang dynasty, he said to his disciple Hong Yan:
My remaining energy is weak, and impermanence is about to arrive. You should stay and continue practicing.
He burned incense, joined his palms, and passed away in the early night. He was 75 years old, and had been a monk for 55 years.
On the 18th day of that month, his stupa was moved to the east hill of the temple's estate east of the capital's eastern suburbs.
Later Tang Dynasty, Changshui, Luoyang, Linglin's Biography, Later Tang Dynasty, Changshui, Luoyang, Linglin's Biography, Shi Linglin, whose surname was Yang, was from Menxiang, Shaanxi Prefecture.
From a young age, his conduct was upright, and he sought to leave the secular world. He received the VimalakÄ«rti SÅ«tra from a teacher in his hometown.
When he reached the age to follow the Dharma, he then received the precepts and studied both the MahÄyÄna and HÄ«nayÄna teachings.
In the Dharma gates of names and numbers, he became thoroughly pure.
The SÅ«tra of AmitÄbha and the MÄdhyamaka-Å›Ästra were well-versed by him, and his fame and light spread far and wide, unmatched in the capital.
He then traveled to Changshui in the south of Luoyang, where he met a donor who had faith in him and built a monastery, where he lectured on the sÅ«tras.
He expounded and propagated one treatise and one sutra for thirty years, each about fifty times.
He recited the Vimalakirti Sutra and the Sutra of the Buddha's Rebirth in Heaven daily as a regular practice.
He practiced with a focused mind and was free from faults. People from far and near revered him, like those who look to a plum tree for water.
In the second year of Qingtai, the year of Biuwei, he passed away at the temple in the town, at the age of seventy-one, with fifty-one years as a monk.
That year, he was moved to the foot of the mountain and cremated according to the Western Region method. His disciples and donors collected his relics and built a stupa for him.
The Biography of Shi Zhenbian of Kaiyuan Temple in Dingzhou during the Later Tang Dynasty. Shi Zhenbian was a person from Zhongshan.
He knew to leave the dust from a young age, and vowed to study and practice when he grew up. His nature was to endure hardship, and people could not bear his worries.
He single-mindedly listened and searched. In his spare time, he wrote sutras with his blood, and also painted standing images of Avalokitesvara Bodhisattva and Maitreya Bodhisattva with his blood.
Once, while practicing walking meditation, he became tired and rested. Two celestial maidens came to disturb him. Bian vowed to them:
My mind is not like a stone. I will curse you with a divine spell.
The crowd did not allow him to leave.
From then on, his practice became superior, and the demons also disappeared without a trace.

Bian carried his books and went to Taiyuan City to study and practice. At that time, the state of Zhongshan and the Later Tang Dynasty of the Li family bordered each other. Fearing that spies might come, the city of Bingzhou did not allow foreign monks to stay.
Because of this, Bian was driven out and stayed in an ancient tomb in the wilderness.
It happened that Emperor Wu was hunting, and the tomb was in the middle of the enclosure.
Bian did not know about this. He was about to enter the city to attend the lecture, but when he saw the flags and cavalry, he shrank back and entered the hole again.

Emperor Wu suspected it and ordered him to be captured. When asked the reason, he examined the tomb and found a mat, desk, inkstone, commentaries, and notes spread out. He then ordered him to enter the palace for offerings.
At that time, Empress Cao deeply respected and revered him. Bian pleaded with the Empress Dowager, saying:
I only wish to study the Dharma. Having been in the royal palace for a long time, I am not happy, as if in shackles.
Emperor Wu allowed him to be free, and he was able to accomplish his studies.
When King Chuang-ping was in power, he returned to Zhongshan to lecture and teach. In repairing old monasteries, all his wishes were fulfilled.
There was a woman surnamed Chen who spread her hair on the ground, asking Bian to step on it.
He compiled the Commentary on the Sutra of Rebirth in the Pure Land, which was valued by students. At that time, those who called it Bian's Commentary were correct.
Later, he passed away in this temple.
Xu Shou, a monk of Dashi Temple in Kuaiji Prefecture during the Later Tang Dynasty.
After receiving full ordination, he studied in the capital, extensively learning both Buddhist and secular knowledge. He lectured on several major sutras and treatises, tirelessly guiding others.
During the Xian Tong period, he was repeatedly summoned to the court to serve as the Left Street Inspector, and those who were his peers all submitted to him.
During the Guang Ming period, the capital was occupied by bandits, and he fled to avoid the danger.
He arrived at Da Sheng Temple in Tai Zhou, and those who had the same interests as him ordered him to lecture on the two sutras of Nirvana and Vimalakirti, which was during the Tian You period.

Because he was indignant at the commentaries on the Chong Fu commentary by teachers such as Qian and Ya, which were either too verbose or too concise, like using water to save water, which would never be able to save anyone, he wrote the Yi Ping Commentary in fourteen scrolls.
During the Tong Guang period, he finally completed the manuscript.

He also lectured on the Commentary on the Abhidharma-koÅ›a, which had a preface by Jia Zeng, the Minister of State, followed by a preface by the monk Yuan Hui, both of which were written in a rich and extensive style, which he had once tasted like dipping his finger in food.
He received the Nirvana Sutra, which was neither too concise nor too verbose, and still refuted many of Xiao Yuan's commentaries, avoiding the stain of a blue fly.
The rest are the Lotus Sutra, the Hundred Dharmas, and the VijÃ±aptimÄtratÄ, each with separate commentaries.

He was by nature somewhat strict and different from others. He did not have a single disciple he could rely on. He would personally cook and prepare the vegetarian meals. If the firewood went out and the fire extinguished, he would blow on it again. If it still did not ignite, he would become angry, fetch water to pour on it, and not eat all day while lecturing.
In his later years, his eyes became very dim. He would ascend the lion seat, wear a bamboo hat, and lecture, wanting his eyes to not blink.
Some criticized him for being disrespectful to the assembly, but he also did not take it to heart.
When King Wusui Qian's troops arrived in Yue, he then went out to pay a visit. The king had long admired him and thus showed him superior courtesy, speaking to him with respect again and again.

During the Qianhua period, at Kaigen Temple in Kuaiji, he was ordered to take the precepts and serve as the examiner for the ordination platform. Among those who held this position in the Wu and Yue regions, he was the first to receive it.
The king memorialized the imperial court, recommending him for the purple robe.
The edict was bestowed by Emperor Zhuangzong, and the messenger brought it to Yingqiu.
At that time, the lecture was on the preface to the commentary on the Sutra of the Buddha's Rebirth, up to If it is a great bell that is empty and receives.
Receiving, he put down the whisk and said:
I have obtained a name without a standard reality. From now on, I will be empty and receive again. My disciples, remember this.
When the report reached the king, the king said:
This monk must have no favor to divide, so why is it called empty reception?

In the second year of the Tongguang era, Zhou passed away. When the sea fleet brought the edict, they checked the day of his death, which was exactly the day of the Qingming Festival. It was indeed in accordance with the words of King Wu.
There are several volumes of Zhou's collected works and more than thirty volumes of his commentaries, which are circulated in the world.
The Biography of Kezhou of Longxing Temple in Hangzhou, Later Tang Dynasty. Shi Kezhou, whose secular surname was Fu, was a person from Jinling.
He became a monk at Jianyuan Temple in his hometown.
His nature was upright and kind, and he earnestly asked for instruction from Qin.
His friend Sheng encouraged him, saying:
If a tree is planted in the wrong place, it will not grow.
Now the Jiangxi area is called the Jiang River, and the area of discussion is called the sea. Why don't you go there to seek learning?

Zhou was moved by his guidance, and with his bag packed, he arrived there. He encountered the flourishing assembly of Dharma Master Yunbiao, and exhaustively studied the great commentaries on the Lotus Sutra by Fazang and Kuiji. Day after day, month after month, he delved into the profound meaning.
At the beginning of the Zhaozong era, he returned from Jiangxi to the area between Tai and Yue, and was ordered to give lectures there.
In the second year of Qianhua in the Liang dynasty, he accepted the invitation of Longxing Temple in Hangzhou to give lectures, with a crowd of monks and laypeople always numbering half a thousand.

The king of Wusuk in the two Zhe regions, Qian of the Chen family, ordered him to give lectures on sutras at night in the Tianbao Hall for the sake of the underworld, and ghosts and spirits appeared in person to guard him. People often saw this.
Once, someone made offerings to the god of the Tongguan shrine. The shaman had been requesting for a long time but the god did not descend. Later, the god spoke through the shaman, saying:
I am following the great deity to the Heavenly Treasure Hall in the west gate to listen to the Dharma and have just returned.
When King Wusuk heard this, he respectfully bestowed a golden ruyi, a bowl, and a set of purple robes, and gave him the title Pure Will and Thorough Understanding of the Mysteries.
In the first year of Tiancheng, he passed away in the Guanyin Cloister of his original residence.

At first, in the fourth year of Qianning of the Zhou dynasty, he stayed at Songshan Temple in Taizhou and lectured on the commentary, which lacked a subcommentary. He then used the commentary to compile five fascicles, called Evaluating the Sutra Subcommentary, and five scrolls of phonetic explanations, explaining Chan Master Xuan's Preface to the Lotus Sutra Subcommentary in one fascicle, which circulated in the left and right of Zhejiang.
His disciples followed one after another without interruption.

The Biography of Zhenhui of Xiangguo Temple in Dongjing of the Later Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Zhenhui of Xiangguo Temple in Dongjing of the Later Tang Dynasty. Shi Zhenhui, whose surname was Bao, was a person from Changshu, Wuzhou.
At the age of thirteen, he left home to become a monk at Longxing Temple in his native prefecture.
His nature was calm and still, and he was meticulous in his work.
After more than a year, he recited the Lotus Sutra, and his daily recitation was two parts like this.
At the age of nineteen, he received the full precepts from a famous teacher in Yangzhou.

Since then, he went west to Yiluo and north to Jinqiao. Wherever there were lecture sessions, he humbly sought to learn. He investigated the sutras and sastras, and exhausted their nature and characteristics. Among his peers, few could match his speed.
As for those who were not his friends or weak companions, he abandoned them as if they were nothing.

In the first year of Tianyou in the Tang Dynasty, he stayed at Xiangguo Temple in the Eastern Capital, lecturing on the Lotus Sutra more than ten times. People did not yet respect him, so he knew that even the sale of rare treasures has its time.
When the Liang family ruled this capital, people and goods were sent in abundance.
In the second year of Zhenming, he met Kong Gong, the governor of Songzhou, who admired his demeanor and knew of his virtuous conduct.
He then performed the rites of a teacher and friend, used his salary to establish a lecture hall for the Lotus Sutra in the Western Pagoda Courtyard, and from this point on, a large number gathered.
He taught them to read the scriptures of the Great Canon, practice the Way at the two times [morning and evening], and diligently strive without fatigue.
He excluded all worldly skills and the words of a hundred schools from discussion, and warned his disciples, saying:
The teachings of heterodox paths confuse the true mind. Useless records do not permeate the mind. Why should we study worldly customs?
I only wish to roar like a lion, not to howl like a jackal.
He only focused on incense, candles, ointments, and sweeping, using the inner courtyard as a place to rest.

On the tenth day of the second month in the second year of Qingtai in the Later Tang, he summoned over fifty disciples, bathed himself with fragrant hot water, had them chant the Upper Birth and pay homage to the Buddha, completely gave away his robes and other belongings, made non-seasonal offerings to the Sangha, and gave half of the offerings to the monks.
On the eleventh day, he faced the sky with his palms joined and said:
The multitude of sages in the sky came to welcome him.
On that day, all the hundred disciples heard the sound of heavenly music, and he passed away in a moment. His secular age was seventy-three, and he had been a monk for fifty-four years.

For more than thirty years, he lectured at the temple. He lectured on the sutras thirty-seven times in total, and read through the Buddhist canon twice. He practiced the method of being reborn in Maitreya's inner court.

On the eighteenth day of the second month of that year, he was buried in the east of the suburbs, at the temple's estate. Thousands of disciples in monastic robes and white robes gathered to see him off, with banners and canopies.
Kanzhi of Changshou Temple in Luoyang of Later Tang, Biography of Kanzhi of Changshou Temple in Luoyang of Later Tang. Shi Kanzhi, whose surname was Ma, was from Gaohou Mountain in Dafang, Fanyang.
At the age of twelve, he had a strong desire to leave the householder's life. He followed Vinaya Master Fazhen of Minzhong Temple.
At the age of fifteen, he became a novice monk. He took leave of his master and went to Zhenzhou to study sutras and treatises.

At that time, Ren Chu, a monk of the Great Flower Garland Monastery, was lecturing on the NyÄyapraveÅ›a. Zhi stopped to hold the book and respectfully listened three times, penetrating the profound meaning, and the assembly praised him as exceptionally outstanding.
There was an old monk named Weimo, a remarkable person in the Buddhist community, who asked Master Chu:
